ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Programming skill.
Critical thinking, evaluation, cost benefit analysis, writing, and many other skills outside of traditional computer science skills.
This class is a great way to start thinking about upper level project organization. Tons of useful lessons, and a fun set of projects (rust > C though)
Knowledge of compute system design principles as well as the intricacies of multiple operating systems.

An exploration of computer systems and how we can apply knowledge from philosophy/psychology into designing better systems. Also an overview of OS kernel implementations, from C/Linux to Rust/Theseus.

This class is as much psychology as it is computer science. As we learned in the class, the process of building computer systems is less about the actual code and much more about the people writing it. This course gave me a much broader perspective on CS as an industry.

The topics from the class are somewhat all over the place, from infinities and abstract algebra to the invention of RFID technology. Nonetheless, I found the breadth refreshing and valuable.

I learned a lot not just about CS design principles in this class, but also about how systems of people, systems inside companies, and systems of general organizations work. I also learned a ton about the history of computer science, computability, probability, and logic, and how all of these things tie into the technology ecosystem that we have today.
It leads us to thinking of the underlying principles of system and human life.
Principles of designing a good computer system.
Principles and philosopy regarding computer system development
Interesting history of computing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course was taught in an outstanding fashion and I would not change a thing.
Overall it was a great course! I think one thing that could make it better is a few more case studies, just to hammer home the ideas we talked about.

Labs we pretty comprehensive, enjoyed learning about the operating systems through completing labs and lectures went over many interesting topics. Would not mind doing another pset for another operating system to understand these concepts more.
I thought it could have used a bit more organization and structure around the lectures, and the assignments were a bit unclear at times.
The lectures don't cover the material you need to know for the psets, and the psets were frustrating.
It's a well organized course.
There could be more guidelines and hints for the programming assignments.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. The course was not only extremely interesting, but also engaging and fair. I would highly recommend to another student.
I would recommend it to anyone interested in software engineering
Yes, good way of learning system design without too much pressure from tests, quizzes and too many assignments. Teacher and TA are very flexible and generous with the course.
Yes! Really chill class and Lin's a great lecturer.
Absolutely - I strongly recommend it, especially with Professor Lin Zhong.

If you're a CS major, this might be the best elective there is. The work is a bit challenging if you're not familiar with linux kernel development, but you are provided ample resources both in class and via office hours to make sure that you not only complete the assignment, but understand it. I want to be clear though the work is challenging, there is not a lot of it. It is not a programming intensive class. The lectures are very entertaining, informative, and easy to understand. I was eager to show up to class every day and when I had to miss I made sure that I got caught up quickly. Prof. Zhong is an amazing professor and you can really tell that he cares about how his students develop not just as CS majors, but as members of society. This has been my favorite class at Yale.
Yes, Lin is a wonderful professor with great perspective and lesson materials for learning beyond the basics in programming intensive courses like 223/323/OS
No, take OS
Sure, it's a organized course with not that heavy workload. Students do learn something from it.
Yes. This course is easy to pass, and contains lots of interesting anecdotes that illustrate the principles.
yes
Yes if you like reading.
